Each year APA partners with the Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW) through their Buddy Poppy program for Memorial Day. Our schools received 8,000 Buddy Poppies from the VFW this year, but due to COVID-19 we were unable to fundraise for them.

Buddy Poppies are assembled by disabled and needy veterans in VA Hospitals. The VFW Buddy Poppy program provides compensation to the veterans who assemble those poppies, provides financial assistance in maintaining state and national veterans' rehabilitation and service programs, and partially supports the VFW National Home For Children.

Please consider contributing to this fund by going to https://www.americanprepfoundation.org/donate.

For more information on the VFW Buddy Poppy program please go to https://www.vfw.org/community/community-initiatives/buddy-poppy.

Thank you!

APA teachers and staff have gone to extraordinary lengths to make learning from home successful for our students. Teacher Appreciation Week is this week, May 4-8. It is the perfect time to thank teachers for their tremendous dedication, creativity, and problem solving during this pandemic.

American Preparatory Education Foundation invites you to nominate a teacher or staff member who you feel is deserving of a little extra thanks. The Foundation will award 3 teachers with a gift and letter of thanks. Letters can be written by you or your child and submitted to Michelle Goudge at mgoudge@americanprepfoundation.org. Or you can use the nomination form at https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1pHx7csPFE2YtzvS20J8M-kRTSJj-qC6g2iGE5m9OUFM/copy. Be sure to share it to the email address above when you are finished.

The deadline is Saturday, May 9, and the winners will be announced on Monday, May 11.

Thank you, Veterans!

American Preparatory Academy believes it is a privilege to honor our veterans and to teach our students about the sacrifices that are required to maintain our nation’s freedoms.

We have held three Veterans Day assemblies this last week at our campuses. Each commemoration has been a reminder of the importance of honoring our great men and women who have served.

At each assembly, students personally thank veterans for their service through songs and speeches. Each veteran receives a commemorative pin and handwritten thank-you letter from an American Prep student.

Today, on Veterans Day, we invite our community to honor those that have gone "downrange" across seas and battlefields. We thank those that have sacrificed weeks, months, and years to engage in struggles both foreign and domestic.

At APA, our students, staff, and families salute you and extend our appreciation that you would sacrifice so much for us.

Thank you, Veterans!

All ages 6 years old and up are welcome! We promise to provide an uplifting, encouraging, and educational experience for all aspiring singers who attend. Register today for $20, or $25 with lunch included! More info and registration available at our website, www.singutah.org.

D3 Debate team wins 2 consecutive region titles
APA Draper 3 Debate team wins 2 consecutive region titles in only its second year. This is a significant accomplishment showcasing the talent and skills of our Draper 3 High School students.

The Region 17 tournament is a one-day competition that took place at Rockwell High School. Our students competed in the following categories: Public Forum(PF), Lincoln Douglas(LD), Spontaneous Argumentation, Impromptu, Extemporaneous Speaking, and Original Oratory.

While our kids won as a team, some students placed in their events. These students were Bradley Blanchard who took 2nd in LD, and Navi Brar, who took 3rd in LD. While still new as a team, APA has become the largest running debate program in our region.

As they moved on to the State Championship, the also did exceptionally well against all 2A schools, winning at least half of their debates. Huck Jones and Caleb Mitchell were able to place 3rd in Public Forum Debate.

Wonderful spotlight on our very own Michelle Mulcahy, Academic Director at Draper 1.

As a former teacher, Michelle Mulcahy appreciates that teachers invest a lot of themselves into their work and need support. Now, as director, her job is to provide that support through training, communication and by being that “calm presence.”

Michelle values the importance of education and finds being on the administrative side equally rewarding because she says by taking care of teachers, students, families and the entire community benefit.

“We find amazing people who care about kids, and we help them to be amazing teachers,” she says. “It all revolves around a desire to do what’s best for kids.”

Last night, APA hosted an expert from UHEAA to come and assist our senior families with the FAFSA application. This is a complex government form. The mostly first-generation families had plenty of questions. The event was so well attended that we had to open three classrooms; we didn’t leave until 8:30 PM when every last person was served!

You could hear moments of joy as students got their estimated grant awards, many received the full amount of $5800. In 2015, Utah seniors collectively left $45 million free grant dollars on the table because only 30% of students filed for a FAFSA. Unacceptable.

College is possible! At APA, we know that having the right information and support is crucial to student success. We also know that all kids can do great things, and we're dedicated to seeing students all the way through to college. Special thanks to Wendolens Ruano and Jen Bodnar for helping make this possible!

Utah APA Parents,

As we encourage our students to be builders of their community, we also like to encourage our parents to be involved in local elections. The State School Board has great influence over our school, and all charter and traditional public schools. We encourage our parents to research the candidates currently running for State School Board, and to make an informed decision this November.

Utahcharters.org has some great resources to help you become acquainted with the candidates. Also, for a large number of our Draper families, there will be a candidate debate held tonight for the District 10 (Draper) candidates. It would be greatly beneficial for our parents to attend such events to make sure that your voices are heard, and that charter schools are represented.

Details:

District 10 State School Board Debate
Location: Channing Hall Charter School
Time: TONIGHT Wednesday, September 28th at 6:30 pm

Please help us make sure that we elect the candidates that will change the education world for the better.

American Prep

Our builders theme for the month of January is: "I am a builder when I am willing to try!" We've talked with our students about how saying the words, "I can't," is really just saying, "I'm not willing to try!" Sometimes we are not willing to try because we are afraid of failure. However, when we don't try because we are afraid of failure, we definitely cannot succeed!

At other times we do try and we fail. Does that mean we should stop trying? Absolutely not! Most people fail on their first try. Usually we fail the first several times we try something. Thomas Edison failed hundred of times. He never gave up! He never gave up! And that is what made him successful. He is one of the greatest builders of all time; all because he was willing to try again, and again, and again, and again! We've challenged the students to remember Thomas Edison when they feel like giving up and know that with enough work, they can accomplish anything!
